awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Sharp arithmetic transitions and universality in one-frequency quasiperiodic systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description
Mathematics provides essential tools for the study and description of many natural phenomena. An important area of research in mathematics is the development of tools to study the movement of different systems (termed dynamical phenomena), which range from the movement of celestial bodies to heart function and fluctuations in the stock market.  This fellowship will initiate a new collaboration between the University of Mississippi (UM) and University of California Irvine (UCI), enabling an extended research visit at UCI. The project will develop  state of the art tools for study of dynamical systems, which will allow scientists to probe systems at different spatial and time scales, revealing properties of systems that are universal. An example of the type of research that has relied on these tools in the past is the description of the transition between the liquid and gas phases (i.e., boiling and evaporation).  A particular focus of this project will be on sharp transitions and universality in two types of systems: relatively simple systems that underlie more complicated systems; and systems arising from quantum physics. This project will lead to advancement of both areas, strengthen the research program in dynamical systems and mathematical physics at UM, and enhance its undergraduate and graduate education.

Technical description
This project involves cutting-edge problems at the interface of dynamical systems and mathematical physics, in particular the spectral theory of Schrödinger operators, which will be approached using the powerful idea of renormalization. The project will focus on sharp arithmetic transitions and universality in quasiperiodic systems, specifically circle maps with breaks and Schrödinger operators. Circle maps with an irrational rotation number are a prototype of quasiperiodic dynamics and are closely related to many other systems, including the Schrödinger cocycles arising from the spectral analysis of Schrödinger operators. The objectives of the project are two-fold: (i) to seek a sharp arithmetic transition for the rigidity of circle maps with a break, i.e., the optimal set of rotation numbers for which a smooth conjugacy between any two maps with the same rotation number in that set, and the same size of the break, is guaranteed; and (ii) to develop a renormalization approach towards explaining the self-similarity of the Hofstadter butterfly and universality in the behavior of eigensolutions, arising when studying the spectrum of one-frequency quasiperiodic Schrödinger operators. Both problems will significantly advance the knowledge in these fields. The second problem would represent significant advancement not only in mathematics, but also in related areas of physics.

por.por_cntn:
The fellowship enabled the PI and a graduate student to conduct research at University of California Irvine (UCI). Their host was Professor Svetlana Jitomirskaya, an expert in mathematical physics and the spectral theory of Schroedinger operators. The PI has collaborated with Professor Jitomirskaya, and expanded his area of research into mathematical physics and spectral theory Schroedinger operators. The student has worked on a joint project with a student of Professor Jitomirskaya. They have also benefited from interaction with other members of UCI and outstanding visitors, as well as the mathematical physics group at Caltech. The PI has worked (in part jointly with the host)  on  cutting-edge problems at the interface of dynamical systems and the spectral theory of Schroedinger operators, using the powerful idea of renormalization. This has resulted in the significant advancement of both areas, expanded the PI's research field, and strengthened research in dynamics and mathematical physics at  the University of Mississippi (UM). It has also established a strong collaboration between UM and UCI. Students at UM now have a possibility to do research in a new area of state of the art mathematics, develop new collaborations across the country, and be more competitive on the job market. 

The PI worked on problems in the direction of sharp arithmetic transitions and universality in quasiperiodic systems, in particular  circle maps and quasiperiodic Schroedinger operators. Circle maps are a prototype of quasiperiodic dynamics and are at the core of many other systems including the Schroedinger cocycles arising from the spectral analysis of Schroedinger operators.  The following objectives have been met: (i) Two transition results for rigidity of circle maps with breaks have been obtained. A local robust Holder rigidity, i.e., Holder rigidity for all irrational rotation numbers, has been established. Absence of C^1-rigidity for circle maps with a break for a set of irrational numbers has been established that, together with an earlier C^1 rigidity result for almost all irrational rotation numbers, provides an almost-sharp transition for the rigidity of these maps; (ii) a renormalization approach has been developed to explain the universality of the Hofstadter butterfly, arising from the spectrum of one-frequency quasiperiodic Schroedinger operators (iii) A new direction of research, at the interface of spectral theory or Schroedinger operators and rigidity of circle maps -- spectral theory of Schroedinger operators over circle maps -- has been initiated: several results have been obtained to establish a  singular-continuous phase (up to the phase transition lines) for Schroedinger operators over circle diffeomorphisms, circle maps with breaks and critical circle maps.These objectives are important and significantly advance the knowledge in these fields. The second objective presents a significant advancement not only in mathematics but also in related areas of physics.

The PI has started a collaboration with one of the well-known mathematicians in mathematical physics and, in particular, spectral analysis of Schroedinger operators, and expanded his area of research. The high-quality research at the UM Department of Mathematics has been boosted and the research strengths of the department have been expanded in a direction that is also important for physics, and various technical fields. This has also boosted the interdisciplinary research at UM and the interaction between the Physics and Mathematics Departments. It has established a strong collaboration with UCI and made our department --- which is of the nation's leaders in producing African American Ph.D.s --- a stronger center for dynamical systems and mathematical physics in the United States. This collaboration has provided students with a possibility to do research in a new area of cutting-edge mathematics, develop new collaborations and acquire experience outside UM.  This all has increased the visibility of the department on national and international scale, and will allow new graduates to be more competitive on the job market. This will also make the University or Mississippi a more attractive place for incoming STEM students.
